senses.definition: to check a piece of work to see if there are any mistakes
examples: Review your work before you turn it in.

senses.definition: to carefully examine or consider something again, especially so that you can decide if it is necessary to make changes
examples: The government will review the situation later in the year.

to review a decision/proposal
Staff performance is reviewed annually.
These ideas will be examined in more detail in Chapter 10.

The government will review the situation later in the year.
We will study the report carefully before making a decision.
This topic will be discussed at greater length in the next chapter.

senses.definition: to read or study information about something, especially in order to reach an opinion about it

senses.definition: to think about past events, for example to try to understand why they happened

senses.definition: to make an official inspection of a group of soldiers, etc. in a military ceremony

senses.definition: to change your opinions or plans, for example because of something you have learned

senses.definition: to change something, such as a book or an estimate, in order to correct or improve it

senses.definition: to prepare for an exam by looking again at work that you have done

senses.definition: an attempt, by a large number of people, to change the government of a country, especially by violent action

senses.definition: a great change in conditions, ways of working, beliefs, etc. that affects large numbers of people

senses.definition: a complete circular movement around a point
examples: The disk rotates at up to 500 revolutions per minute.

senses.definition: a thing that you are given because you have done something good, worked hard, etc.
examples: a financial reward
reward for something a reward for good behaviour
reward for doing something You deserve a reward for being so helpful.

a reward for hard work
rewards for employees who do their jobs well

senses.definition: an amount of money that is offered to somebody for helping the police to find a criminal or for finding something that is lost

to give something to somebody because they have done something good, worked hard, etc.
examples: reward somebody for something She was rewarded for her efforts with a cash bonus.
reward somebody for doing something He rewarded us handsomely (= with a lot of money) for helping him.

reward somebody with something She started singing to the baby and was rewarded with a smile.
reward somebody/something Our patience was finally rewarded.

highly rewarded occupations

senses.definition: a strong regular repeated pattern of sounds or movements

senses.definition: a series of movements, jokes, etc. that are part of a performance

senses.definition: a list of instructions that enable a computer to perform a particular task
a number of people standing or sitting next to each other in a line; a number of objects arranged in a line
examples: row of somebody/something There is a row of trees in front of the house.

senses.definition: used in the names of organizations that serve or are supported by a king or queen

senses.definition: impressive; suitable for a king or queen

senses.definition: to move your hand, a cloth, etc., backwards and forwards over a surface while pressing it

rub something + adv./prep. He rubbed a hand wearily over his eyes.

senses.definition: to be very poor, stupid, etc.
to keep reminding somebody in an unkind way of their past mistakes

rubber gloves

examples: a ball made of rubber

senses.definition: made in a simple, basic way

senses.definition: looking or feeling very healthy

examples: His face was running with sweat.
The bathroom floor was running with water.

senses.definition: if the colour runs in a piece of clothing, etc. when it gets wet, the colour comes out of the material and spreads into other pieces of clothing, etc. in the same water
examples: The colour ran and made all my underwear pink.

senses.definition: to melt
examples: The wax began to run.

senses.definition: to become different in a particular way, especially a bad way
examples: The river ran dry (= stopped flowing) during the drought.
Supplies are running low.
We understand that feelings are running high on this issue
We've run short of milk.
You've got your rivals running scared.

senses.definition: to be at or near a particular level
examples: Inflation was running at 26 per cent.

senses.definition: to continue for a particular period of time without stopping
examples: run for something Her last musical ran for six months on Broadway.
run from A to B The course runs from June 25th to August 27th.
This debate will run and run!

senses.definition: to operate or be legally acceptable for a particular period of time
examples: The permit runs for three months.
The lease on my house only has a year left to run.

senses.definition: to happen or progress at the time or in the way mentioned
examples: + adv./prep. Programmes are running a few minutes behind schedule this evening.
Everything is running according to plan.
Her life had always run smoothly before.
The murderer was given three life sentences, to run concurrently.

senses.definition: to be a candidate in an election for a political position, especially in the US
examples: Obama ran a second time in 2012.
run for somebody/something Hilary Clinton ran for president in 2016.
He ran unsuccessfully for the Senate in New York.
run in something She is planning to run in the parliamentary election.

senses.definition: to bring or take something into a country illegally and secretly
examples: run something + adv./prep. He used to run guns across the border.
She made money by running drugs.

senses.definition: to have particular words, contents, etc.
examples: Their argument ran something like this…
+ speech ‘Ten shot dead by gunmen,’ ran the newspaper headline.

senses.definition: to print and publish an item or a story
examples: On advice from their lawyers they decided not to run the story.

senses.definition: to do a test, an experiment, etc.
examples: run something on something The doctors decided to run some more tests on the blood samples.
run something The two experiments are run in parallel.
The company is running clinical trials of the new drug.

senses.definition: if tights or stockings run, a long thin hole appears in them
to be pleased to do what somebody wants
examples: She knew she had only to call and he would come running.

senses.definition: to run in order to escape from somebody/something
to treat somebody badly and not worry about their feelings
working fully and correctly
examples: It will be a lot easier when we have the database up and running.
We soon had the sound system up and running.

senses.definition: a person or an animal that runs, especially one taking part in a race
examples: a long-distance/cross-country/marathon runner
He was a fast runner.
a list of runners (= horses in a race) and riders
She is the world's greatest marathon runner.
She was a good runner and soon caught up with Tom.
Some of the country's top long-distance runners are competing in this 10km race.
There are several promising young 1500-metre runners coming through.

senses.definition: a person who takes goods illegally into or out of a place
examples: a drug runner

senses.definition: a narrow piece of metal, plastic or wood that something slides on or can move along on
examples: the runners of a sledge

senses.definition: a plant stem that grows along the ground and puts down roots to form a new plant
a long narrow piece of cloth or carpet on a piece of furniture or on the floor
a person in a company or an organization whose job is to take messages, documents, etc. from one place to another
a shoe that is used for running or doing other sport in
to leave or run away from somewhere in a hurry, especially to avoid paying a bill or receiving a punishment
the action or sport of running
examples: to go running
long-distance/cross-country running
running shoes

senses.definition: the activity of managing or operating something
examples: the day-to-day running of a business
the running costs of a car (= for example of fuel, repairs, insurance)
Mr Matengu was overseeing the smooth running of the exhibition.
She took over the running of the organization.
They are there to ensure the safe running of the event.

senses.definition: the activity of bringing something such as drugs, guns, etc. into a country secretly and illegally
examples: drug-running

senses.definition: having some/no chance of succeeding or achieving something
to set the speed at which something is done; to take the lead in doing something
connected with or like the countryside
examples: rural areas
Belarus is predominantly rural.
the rural community/population
a rural economy
rural America
a rural way of life
a small, quiet, rural village
a rural development program
At the end of the 17th century England was still overwhelmingly rural.
Sri Lanka's predominantly rural population
the ideal of suburban or semi-rural living
He grew up in a predominantly rural area.
Laramie is a small rural town in Wyoming.

senses.definition: a sudden strong movement or action
examples: rush for something Shoppers made a rush for the exits.
in a rush The words came out in a rush.
in the rush to do something She was trampled in the rush to get out.
They listened to the rush of the sea below.
The door blew open, letting in a rush of cold air.
He had a rush of blood to the head (= suddenly lost control of himself) and punched the man.
rush towards something (figurative) The ancient art is all but lost in the city's headlong rush towards industrialisation.
an adrenaline/a sugar rush

senses.definition: a situation in which you are in a hurry and need to do things quickly
examples: What's the rush?
‘I'll let you have the book back tomorrow.’ ‘There's no rush.’
in a rush I can't stop—I'm in a rush.
The note looked like it had been written in a rush.
in a rush to do something I’m not in any rush to get back to work.
The trip to Paris was all a mad rush.
a rush job (= one that has been done quickly)

senses.definition: a situation in which people are very busy and there is a lot of activity
examples: Book now and avoid the last-minute rush.
The evening rush was just starting.
the Christmas rush
We've had a rush on at the office, dealing with the backlog of orders.

senses.definition: a sudden strong emotion or sign of strong emotion
examples: a sudden rush of excitement/fear/anger
She experienced a sudden rush of emotion.
He felt a sudden rush of excitement.
When she heard his voice it was with a rush of relief.

senses.definition: a sudden feeling of extreme pleasure or excitement
examples: Parachuting will give you the rush of a lifetime.
Users of the drug report experiencing a rush that lasts several minutes.

senses.definition: a sudden large demand for goods, etc.
examples: There's been a rush on umbrellas this week.

senses.definition: a tall plant like grass that grows near water. Its long thin stems can be dried and used for making baskets, the seats of chairs, etc.
examples: rush matting

senses.definition: the first prints of a film before they have been edited
an occasion when a player or players run towards a player on the other team who has the ball
examples: There was a rush on the quarterback.

senses.definition: an occasion when a player runs forward with the ball
examples: Johnson carried the ball an average of 6 yards per rush.

senses.definition: the time when parties are held for students who want to join a fraternity or sorority
examples: rush week
a rush party

senses.definition: to force somebody/be forced to leave a place quickly
examples: He was soon given the bum's rush from the club.

senses.definition: to move or to do something with great speed, often too fast
examples: We've got plenty of time; there's no need to rush.
the sound of rushing water
+ adv./prep. Don't rush off, I haven't finished.
I've been rushing around all day trying to get everything done.
The children rushed out of school.
Firefighters rushed to the scene and extinguished the blaze.
When I fell forwards onto the ice, Michael came rushing to my aid, helping me up giving me an encouraging smile.
His wife immediately rushed to his defence (= defended him against attack or criticism).
Beachgoers rushed to the rescue of three boys as they were pulled out to sea in a rip tide.
My college years seemed to rush past.
She rushed back upstairs.
rush to do something People rushed to buy shares in the company.
rush something We had to rush our meal.
She was rushing around madly looking for her bag.
Two men came rushing into the room.
Whenever her little brother was upset, Jane rushed to the rescue.
a train rushing headlong down the track
A surge of joy rushed through her body.

senses.definition: to transport or send somebody/something somewhere with great speed
examples: Ambulances rushed the injured to the hospital.
Relief supplies were rushed in.
He was rushed home immediately.

senses.definition: to do something or to make somebody do something without thinking about it carefully
examples: We have to be careful not to rush to judgment.
rush into doing something We don't want to rush into having a baby.
rush into something Let us not rush headlong into this crazy project without careful consideration.
rush somebody Don't rush me. I need time to think about it.
rush somebody into something/into doing something I'm not going to be rushed into anything.

senses.definition: to flow strongly
examples: The water rushed in through the hole in the ship's hull.

senses.definition: to try to attack or capture somebody/something suddenly
examples: A group of prisoners rushed an officer and managed to break out.
Fans rushed the stage after the concert.

senses.definition: to run into somebody who has the ball
to move forward and gain ground by carrying the ball and not passing it
to give a lot of attention to somebody, especially to a student because you want them to join your fraternity or sorority
examples: He is being rushed by Sigma Nu.

senses.definition: to be extremely busy; to have too many things to do
examples: Weekdays are slow in the restaurant, but at weekends the staff are rushed off their feet.

senses.definition: people with little experience try to do the difficult or dangerous things that more experienced people would not consider doing
